editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by W. H. for Iohn Tey, and are to be ſold at his ſhop at the Sign of the White Lion in the Strand, neer the New Exchange, 1651.

div.head: To the truly Noble, Sir IOHN SIDLEY Baronet.
div.p:
LIke to a Young Student in Negromancy, whoſe Itch to Rarity makes him Attempt the raiſing what hee wants skill to lay, I have adventured in this little Common-wealth of Poetry to beget ſome Diſtractions that cannot be reconcil'd without your Patronage. Sir, you have the fame for Piety and Love to your Country, and have ſo equally ballanced your Actions in theſe diſtemper'd times, that you have not only Merited the title Apollo gave to Socrates, but
drawn all mens eies, Loves, and admiration upon you. Amongſt the number of which your honourers, A Stranger tenders his offering; And though it is naked of worth, Yet the Property of your acceptance will be ſhelter ſufficient to it, and him, who, next to your pardon, ſhall endeavour to deſerve the title of

closer.signed: Your moſt humble and faithfull Servant, J: TATHAM.

div.head: TO My dear Friend Mr JOHN TATHAM, On his Excellent Play, The Diſtracted State.
div.l: I Do not write in confidence my fame
May lift you up, or hoiſt you to a Name:
I of my own defects too knowing am
To hope ſupport you, While my ſelf am lame;
And th' world ſo well your Merits underſtand,
They do not need advancement by my hand.
Nor do I labour to be thought a Wit
Becauſe in you I do approve of it.
What makes you ſhine, does make me not diſpair
To hope a glimmering in the ſelf ſame air:
To Love I'm vow'd too; not that wayward toy
That for theſe thouſand yeers writes himſelf Boy;
Who makes the Lord and Lady ſtill to meet,
As ſure as in a Country Dance wee ſee't.
'Tis motley, juſt like Cheeſes where I've been,
Checkquer'd, one ſquare of white, and one of green;
'Tis at the beſt imperfect, ſuch a pair
Like Doublets in the middle joyned are;
While maſculine affections, ſuch as mine,
Like Diamonds, entire and cleerly ſhine.
To Womankind a while I bid adue,
And only now enamour'd am of you.
And certain, 'tis no miracle in me,
T' whom Civill War hath been a nurſery,
That I in ſtrict obedience to my fate,
Do fall in Love with your Diſtracted State

div.head: To my worthy Friend Mr. IOHN TATHAM, on his Excellent Tragedy, The Diſtracted State.
div.l: GOod Wine does need no buſh, nor does thy wit
Want our ſupporting, this thy Play is writ
With ſo much judgement, and ſo firm a hand,
It ſhall againſt the ſtormes of Envy ſtand
A Monument to thy fame: for if we may
Conclude Language and Plot do make a Play,
Here they are met, each Scene and Act ſo well
Follow'd, that one the other doth excell;
And their contention does ſo neatly end,
As though thou didſt a ſecond Rape intend
Vpon our ſenſe, drawing our greedy eyes
To read, till they themſelves do Sacrifice.
For he that loves to Feaſt on a good line,
Will never think he has enough of thine.

div.head: To my moſt Deſerving Friend I. T. Vpon his Play, The Diſtracted State.
div.l: VVHen I that ſweet Elixar of thy lines
Taſted, and found within thoſe golden Mines
That rare refin'd delight, in which 'tis ſin
Not to be loſt or catch'd in fancies gin,
I did thy worth ſo cleer a Victor ſee
The Lawrell could be due to none but thee.
I cannot offer Hecatombs of praiſe,
Nor Altars to thy lofty fancy raiſe;
This well meant Tribute I can only pay;
Wit's high Meridian glorifies thy Play.

list.item: Archias, A Noble Lord, their Kinſman.
Miſſellus, Provinciall of Vallis de Noto, friend to the King.
Planetius, Provinciall of Mona, made by Mazares.
Philiſtus, A young Lord, Minion to Mazares.
Adulanter, A baſe fawning Lord, A Buffoon.
Icetis, Governour of a Caſtle in Palermo.
Harmonia, Daughter to Cleander, and Miſtris to Archias.

div.head: ACTUS 1. SCENA 1.
div.stage: Enter Mazares, the Archbiſhop of Monreall, Cleander, Agathocles, Epecides, Philiſtus, Adulanter, &c.
Mazares aſcends the Chaire of State, the Archbiſhop puts the Crown on's head; then, all, but Agathocles, cry Long live Mazares lawfully King of Sicily.

sp.speaker: AGATHOCLES.
sp.l: HEaven where's thy Vengeance?
Canſt thou endure this Mockery?

div.stage: Agathocles kneeles with his back towards them, aſide.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: We thank you all. But why Agathocles
Appears ſuch trouble on thy brows, are we
Unwelcome to thy wiſhes?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: How Sir! Pardon me.
Who dares ſay you are?
You are my King,—Is it not ſo Gentlemen?
The Raies that from your Brothers Diadem
Gilded this Kingdom are put out, and now
From you our riſing Sun, we muſt expect
A Vertuall fervor. Obedience is my ſafety.
My wiſhes! trifles, what may you not Command?
If you but will, my life is not my own.
One frown may Rivet me, I am deſign'd
To be but what you pleaſe, and when, no longer.
I am your poor Submiſſive.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: You Miſconſtre
The power of Kings, they dare not but be juſt.
That Crown can ne'r ſit faſt that takes it's riſe
From others ruine.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Out Impoſture—

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: My Lords I could have wiſh'd
The Peoples and your Loves had ſpar'd this ſolemnity
Until another time, a time that might
Have prov'd more fit for Triumph; for though Heaven
Hath wreath'd our Brows with Victory, our thoughts
Are not at peace.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Nor ever will be til
By their continuall motion they have brought
All into Publike ruine.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: The Care of th' Common ſafety
O'rwhelms our Joy and makes it ſeem unſeaſonable.
Repoſe after ſo long a toile of War would bee
Perfume unto our Senſes, but we muſt not
Prefer our own before the Peoples quiet.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Machivell thou art an Aſſe, a very Aſſe to him

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: My Lords, you are my witneſſes,
The Publike wrong, and not Ambitious hopes
Of Government, Oblieg'd me to this Quarrell
(The Peoples and not mine) againſt my Brother;
The Juſtice of which cauſe gave us Succeſs.
Heaven knowes, had he not bin their Enemy,
I ſhould have emptied ev'ry vein I have
T'have ſerv'd him. Nature and Duty held
Strong Conflicts in my blood, Nature promoting
One while my Brothers right, untill my Duty
Unto my Country with Diviner Reaſon
O'reame me, and diſcover'd the ſad Scene
Of a ſinking People, and a riſing Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Does Heaven hear this, and puniſheth not?

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: For my part, my Lords,
Though the affection of the People Circles
My Temples with a Crown, I ſhall not wear it
Longer than they 'ſteem me worthy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Moſt ſingular Prince.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Moſt ſingular Devill.—

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: My Lord Arch-Biſhop,
You are the Church's Vine, and we the Elm
Of th' Common-wealth, our flouriſhing Eſtates
Depend on one another; by Heaven's hand
We are Contracted, and muſt ſhare all fortunes,
Or good, or bad. The Iewels of a Crown
Retain not Luſtre longer than they have
Vertue from th'Church, and that ſhe's glorious;
Nor can ſhe be ſo longer than we are ſo,
Her ſtrength and welfare doth conſiſt in ours.
Let not this ſuddain change
Poſſeſſe her with a fear of her Ecclips.
Sh'as a Protector now, that will expoſe
His life a Sacrifice to preſerve her Purity.
We ſhall not be remiſſe to ſatisfie
What lies on our part towards her, and what
From her belongs to us we need not intimate,
You have a Senſe my Lord, can reach at things
And their Neceſſities.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: My Duty ſhall not be wanting, my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: The Church-man will turn Pander to him.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: My Lords,
W'are not inſenſible of the Peoples burthen
By keeping up our Armies, but neceſſity
That makes men Act what they would not, Compels it;
We are not yet ſecur'd againſt the Malice
Of our late vanquiſh'd Brother, there's a faction
That waits an opportunity to befriend him,
Beſide his hopes in Italy; thoſe clouds over,
We doubt not but a fair day wil give birth
Unto the Peoples happineſſe and ours.
In the mean time my Lords be it your Care
To ſtop the current of their Cries, and keep
Us fair in their opinion.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: As Hel's Projector.
Down, down big heart, thoul't hang me elſe.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: My Lord,
Let Reaſon moderate your Paſſions,
They are two violent, and may prove your Enemies.

div.l: Mazares wants not Hands.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Nor I a Heart
To dare his worſt; oh Epecides

div.l: I have liv'd too long to ſee this day.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: My Lords, we know
Crowns are but glorious burthens, and the weight
Requires more heads than one to bear it up.
You are th' approved Pilots of the State,
Acquainted with all Creekes, and Rockes where danger
Hides his deſtroying-head, and wiſely can
Steer her, ſhould th' Malice of a Forraign Foe
Swell to a Tempeſt, or Malignant breaths
At home threaten her Ruine; on your faiths
Depends ours and her ſafety.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Moſt gracious Sir,
You have out-done even Expectation? and
The Beams of Vertue that ſhoot from you
Out-ſhine the Glory of your Diadem,
And bind our lives unto your Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: May we owne our lives no longer
Than they perform thoſe offices of Duty
Your Vertues do Command them to.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: We owe much to your Loves,
And ſhall engroſſe a time to pay the Debt
Your Merits call upon us; wee'l divide
The happineſſe, if any wait upon
A Crown, amongſt you.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: When hee's warm in's Seat,
They ſhall as little dare to claime his Promiſe,
As the poor Crane his reward from the Lyon,
When hee had pull'd the Bone out of his throat.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Reſtrain your ſelf,
Ther's little Revenge in words, but words may be
Revenged, be advis'd.

sp.speaker: Adulan.
sp.l: May never Care breed feavors in your blood,
Nor troubles raiſe a Palſie in your Scepter;
May ſtil Succeſſe attend your Enterprizes,
And Conqueſts beget Conqueſts, till you write
Your Self the Worlds great Monarch.

sp.speaker: Archbi.
sp.l: May Heaven's eye
Keep Sentinel while you repoſe, that no
Trayterous Attempts may reach your Sacred Perſon.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Now may the Grones of dying men, the cries
Of Widdows, Orphans, and defloured Virgins,
Together with his Brother's wrongs continually
Keep him awake, till with diſtracted rage
(For want of Reſt) he doth become his own
Dire executioner.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: What meanes this? Agathocles?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I have bin at my Prayers too.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: We thank you, and ſhall
Endeavour to deſerve ſo far,
You ſhall not have Cauſe to repent them.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I beleeve no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Lead on my Lords,
With upright Care we ſhall diſcharge our truſt;
Kings are no longer Kings, than they are juſt.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: My Lord Epecides, a word,
The King may ſpare us two; I may preſume
We are as little needed as regarded.
If that thy looks deceive me not, thou art
Yet free from this diſeaſe, this Itch of Honour,
Which ſo transformes us into Servile flattery.
Art ſwell'd with lofty thoughts?

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: They reach no higher
Than th' Publike good, which they devoutly wiſh,
Though want a power to Compaſſe.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Th'art honeſty it ſelfe;
And to thy Boſome as my Sanctuary,
My Soul ſhall fly to eaſe it ſelf of what
Would burſt me to keep longer.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: My Lord, you may
Be confident I have a Soul as big
With Grief as you, that fain would be deliver'd,
If Reaſon would turn Midwife.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Falſe Cleander
Hath made the Field drunk with his Countrey's blood,
To ſet up an Uſurper.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: It is pretended
The Peoples Preſſures and continuall Calmours
Enforc'd the War.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Kindl'd by the fire
Broke from Mazares boſome, whoſe Ambitious
Deſire of Rule, bred the ill humors in
The eaſily corrupted Multitude,
Who, led by their pernicious hopes, that he
Would bring on better daies, gave breath unto
Their Monſtrous fury, and like a deluge,
Brake forth and ſanke the Fortunes of Evander:
That he poor Prince, having no other Arke
Of Preſervation than his Innocence,
And faith he had in's friends, did fly to them
Whoſe ſhelter ſerv'd him but for a ſhort time,
For they with him at laſt were overwhelm'd.
But Epecides be thou confident,
Though Hell hath further'd the Uſurpers Plot,
And ſmooth'd it with ſucceſſe, Vengeance will reach him.
Though heaven be ſlow it's puniſhment is ſure.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Hear but Cleander,
Philiſtus, Adulanter, and the reſt,
And they will tell you Providence and Juſtice
Sate on their Weapons points to puniſh Tyranny;
And that our Kingdom by Mazares wiſdom,
Will flouriſh in a far better Eſtate,
Than in Evanders time.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Ambition wants not ſnares
To Catch Vulgar Credulity, and carry
On their Deſignes cleere to the end they aime at.
They are the Canes and Truncks through which th' Uſurper
Speaks to promote his purpoſes, and blaſt
All good in's Brother, and Ecclips his right.
Is not Planetius, the firſt bold Traytor,
Of Mona made Provinciall? Is not Cleander
As big with hopes and Expectation?
Does not Philiſtus fawn, and Court to out
Miſsellus the Provinciall of Vallis de Noto.
Credit ſuch Sycophants?

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Miſsellus is Noble,
And if Mazares look not well about him,
Evander may have an after Game to Play,
Miſsellus was his Creature.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Where e'r he be,
Though fortune left his Party, he retaines
A Minde invincible.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: No queſtion but
The State was much diſtemper'd, and Evander
Was not without his faults.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: People diſpos'd for Change,
Survey the Vices of their Prince through Opticks
That rather multiply than leſſen them:
And what is in themſelves but Criminall,
Is in their Prince held horrid, as the Symptome
To the diſeaſe of Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: And dare correct;
That in their Prince they would not in themſelves
Have taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: But allow there were
Some things might grieve the People; Wiſe Experience
Gives us to know that in th' lopping of Trees,
The skilfull hand prunes but the lower Branches,
And leaves the Top ſtill growing to Extract
Sap from the Root, as meaning to Reform,
Not to Deſtroy. I tell thee Epecides,
Th' Exceſſe of what was good in Prince Evander,
Might Stock the barren breaſt' of the Uſurper.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Men never rate their goods ſo highly
As when th'are rob'd of them. It is ſome eaſe
To our afflictions, that we can thus vent
Our Griefes to one another, for we muſt
Deſpair of other remedy.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Very true,
If we continue Children, and adore
The Rod corrects us, kiſſe it till we ſmart for't,
Enthrone baſe Fear in Valours royal Seat,
Let it Lord o'r our Spirits, till our blood
Forſake its heat, and become Ice: But if
We do retain the Glory of our Anceſtors,
(Whoſe Aſhes will riſe up againſt our dulneſſe;)
Shake off our Tameneſſe, and give way to Courage,
We need not doubt (inſpir'd with a juſt rage)
To break the necks of thoſe that would yoke ours.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: I but—

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Thoſe Buts deſtroy us; are you willing
To ſit in th' dark and never ſee the Sun;
With a beſotted Patience ſee your goods
Rifled, and your Inheritance tane from you,
Unleſſe you to ſecure his quiet will
Part with your own, and by compliance baniſh
The peace your Conſcience yet is happy in?

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: You know my Spirit's not ſo chill
But I would know a way, preſcribe you one
That's paſſable, I ſhall not onely run
My Fortunes with you, but make all the friends
And neereſt Allies I have as ready minded
To do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: To a Reſolved Minde
Nothing ſeemes difficult—Archias has a Noble gallant Spirit.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Hee ever was a friend to Vertue, and's of Mazares line too.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Unfold the Myſtery.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: What would you ſay if—he's wellbelov'd and active.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Doe you ſuſpect me?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: No, but hold here's ſome upon us.

sp.speaker: Meſſen.
sp.l: Which is the Lord Philiſtus or Cleander, either will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: What is your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: I've Letters to the King.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Whence came you?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: From Meſſina.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: How fares the Lord Planetius?

sp.speaker: Meſſe.
sp.l: His Honor is in health, I'd faine be diſcharg'd.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: What news, what news, wee'l bring you to the King.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Extreme good Gentlemen, the late Tyrant after his defeat going for Italy, was ſurpriz'd by ſome of Tyche, in the Province of Vall • s de Noto, killd, and caſt into the River; a death too good for him.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: So Sir—

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Oh forbear—But hear me friend is this newes certain?

sp.speaker: Meſſe.
sp.p: My Lord Planetius the Provinciall of Mona had it ſo Sir, and he hath ſent the ſame unto the King▪ I can ſay no more on't Sir, pleaſe you to bring me to thoſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Ther's enough in Court to ſhew you, you may walk thither Sir—

sp.speaker: Meſſe.
sp.l: I could have done that without all this doe Sir—

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Paſſion's too much your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Dog! a death too good for him?

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: What think you now on th'buſineſſe you were upon?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I am beſide my ſelfe, my Courage leaves me,
And Reaſon tels me now I muſt be tame.
The King—

div.stage: Enter Mazares, Cleander, Philiſtus, Adulanter, &c. Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Were not the Villaines found.

sp.speaker: Meſſen.
sp.l: I do not know and't pleaſe your Majeſty.
The King ſeemes to be troubl'd at this News.
Ile change my Note—'tis like they were,
For w'heard the Provinciall of Vallis de Noto had
Appointed the death of ſome body.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: He did but Juſtice then; Oh Philiſtus
And you my honoured Lords, our Grieſes want utterance;
He was our Brother, though our Countries Enemy,
And they have tane away a part of us
That ſent him hence; It was a Deed (though Heavens
Juſt hand was in't) we cannot but Lament.
Your Pardon Supreme powers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Moſt pious Prince.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Blame us not my Lords. We ſay again
He was our Brother, and We cannot ſtop
The Courſe of Nature.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Can this he reall!

sp.speaker: Meſſen.
sp.l: He was a Gracious Prince, ther's the truth on't.
I could weep too for him.

sp.speaker: Adula.
sp.l: How you Villaine?

sp.speaker: Meſſe.
sp.p: Why the King is not offended with me I hope? alas I have Nature in me too, good, Vertuous Prince, Evand • r.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Haſt thou a mind to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Meſſe.
sp.p: How! Is the Wind at that door. No Sir, not for e'r a dead Prince in Chriſtendome; your Majeſty may ſpare your teares, for in truth and verity he was but ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Friend didſt not ſay
That th' Actors were puniſh'd by Miſsellus.

sp.speaker: Meſſe.
sp.l: So I heard an't like your Highneſſe.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Tis ſtrange
Planetius writes not ſo, but it's very likely;
Miſsellus has in many things been ſeen
Ready and Active for him, and no doubt
Would now—

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Come, Come, Miſſellus growes too popular,
Your Majeſty may think on ſome more faithfull.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: We gueſſe your meaning— Philiſtus,
We ſhall diſpatch you upon ſome affaires,
As ſoon as we can ſhake this ſadnes off,
And our Mind's fit for buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It becomes my Duty to wait your
Highneſſe pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.p: Fellow attend our Secretary for a Confirmation of the Provinciallſhip of Mona to Planetius.
sp.l: Come my Lords.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: Begon ſo ſoon my Lord? y'are hardly entred
My Father houſe. Though th' entertainment comes
Short of your Merits, My Lord, beleev't y'are welcome
To poor Harmonia.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Th'art rich in all that's good,
And that's a Dower Queens would be glad to boaſt of.
Since thy deſcent to love me, I'm exalted
Above a Monarch's happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Harmo.
sp.l: And part ſo ſoon?
You have ſome other Miſtris whoſe heaven
Depends upon your Viſit.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Pretty Jealouſie,
How ſweetly it becomes her; Beleeve me deareſt,
By the bleſt hopes I have in thee, Not any
Beauty in Cicily (if there can any be
Beſides thy ſelfe; for in thee is the full
Perfection of all Beauty met) has part
Of the leaſt thought of mine.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: You ſhall not go though yet.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Thy Father—wilt thou now Licenſe me to go;
I'le ſee thee e're the Sun be ſix hours older.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: My Lord Archias you have honour'd me
Exceedingly by this your Viſit. I hope my comming
Does not remove you hence.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: My good Lord,
Excuſe me I beſeech you, did not Buſineſſe
Of much Concernment call me hence, I ſhould
Account that time wel ſpent wherin I might
Serve you and your fair Daughter.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Pleaſure your ſelf my Lord.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: I am your Lordſhips Servant—adue Sweet.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Harmonia,
I gueſſe this Young Lord loves thee,
His often Viſits promiſe ſome ſuch buſineſs;
But I'd not have you Countenance it.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: Why I beſeech you Sir?
You have bin pleas'd to laviſh forth his prayſes
Beyond the Common Character; I've heard you ſay
(With Pardon Sir) hee had much Vertue in him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And has ſo, but he cannot bring his Heart
T'affect this King, although he be his Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: That is no Crime worthy my Notice Sir,
Much leſſe my diſreſpect. Pray give me leave
To uſe him but with that Civility
Becomes the Education of your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My intents
Fly higher to advance thee, if I live,
And that the King perform his Royal word,
(As that he dares not but doe) thou ſhalt ſtand
In Competition with a Queene for Greatneſſe.
Mazares is too weak a Politician,
To think my vaſt Soul can bee hemm'd within
The Circle of a Province, when a Kingdome
Will ſcarce contain it. No, I do but take
This as a Spot of Earth to what I aim at.
I mean to Match thee Girle unto ſome Prince,
By whoſe Aſſiſtance I'l reach the Aſcendent,
The Royall Seat Harmonia, And then
Wee are thy Princely Father: Dos't not Noiſe
Rarely my Girle, the very Sound inſpires
My Soul with flames of Majeſty—Go on Cleander,
'Till Neighbouring Princes wondring at thy Fate,
With trembling Scepters dread their own Eſtate.

div.head: ACT 2. SCE. 1.
div.stage: Enter Mazares, Philiſtus, Adulanter, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: PHiliſtus ſir,
Sit Adulanter—who waites there?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We an't like your Grace.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Bring us Wine,
Wee are diſpos'd to drown our Brothers Memory,
And its appendent Sorrowes in a full
Bowl of rich Wine.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Done like your Princely ſelf.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: What ſhould we
Contract our Youth to Cares for, waſte the heat
Beats in our agile veines, and draw upon
Our head a Snowy-Perrywig before
Age claims it? We are reſolv'd to make
Our blooming Yeers no Prey for Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: You are our Sun, and we the Infant Plants
That take life from you; when your Brow is Clowded
We droop and Pine, as wanting heat; your Highneſſe
Now ſhews your ſelf in Glory; and our heads
That lately were preſt down with diſcontent
Look up to bleſſe the Change.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Your Highneſſe put
Us all in fear you would Convert your Court
Into a Monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, into a Mouſe-trap rather.
Philiſtus to thee.—Fellow let not any
Enter the Preſence if thou regard'ſt thy ſafety.
'Tis hop'd our Subjects, will allow us a time
Of Mirth after our toil for them.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Whether they will or not, your Majeſty has power to take it.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: How e'r we ſeem'd to take our Brothers death,
'Thas brought on our ſecurity, for ſuch
As durſt before ſpeak loud and big, now dare not
Be ſeen to Whiſper 'gainſt us.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Tis a point of Policy,
High as your Highnes ſafety to keep them
At ſuch an Awfull diſtance; ther's Epecides —

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: A Cloſe and cunning Sophiſter, he carries
A fire within him ſcarce to be diſcern'd.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Agathocles comes not much ſhort of him.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: He has a daring Soul, and does attract
The lewd Licentious People, as the fire
That draws ill Vapours to't, but w'are reſolv'd
He and the reſt of's Inſolent Crew ſhall meet
Our Juſtice if they Submit not.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Your Majeſtie's brow
Is too ſerene, ſomething of Wrath there ſeated
Would ſeem far better.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Wher's our Secretary.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Call the Kings Secretary

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Haſt done the Patent we gave Order for?

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: 'Tis ready for your Majeſties Signing.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Give us Ink,—ſo—Philiſtus,
We have Iuſt cauſe to doubt Miſſellus faith too,
And therefore will remove him, and on thee
Confer the honour. He is ſeated like
A Thorn in th'Heart of Cicily, and muſt be
Cut off leſt he ſpread farther, and do gore us.
Take this as earneſt of our Love to thee,
Whoſe Loyalty we are aſſur'd of.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fame
Shall ſpread your Royall Bounty through the World,
And may leave to Be when I forget
To be your Highneſſe Servant.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Cleander had
Our promiſe for't, but We do know him one
Of an unconſtant Spirit, full of Spleen;
A Mind high and unbounded, and to drive
On his own ends, will enter into League
With Turke or Devill; therefore tis not ſafe
For us to lay a truſt of ſo high conſequence
On ſuch a frail foundation, One whoſe faith
Complies with every Winde, and ſtrikes his Sailes
With every Tide and Change. But
You drink ſlowly.—Come to thy
Good Journey.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: The King is private.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I muſt ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Who's that ſo loud there?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: The Lord Cleander.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Tell him 'tis not our pleaſure to be ſpoke with.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: My Lord you hear the King.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My Buſineſſe is of Concernment,
I will enter—How's this? ſurrounded
With his Flatterers; tis like to be
A State well govern'd.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Sir, you are Uncivill.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What mean you Royall Sir?

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Y'are ſawcy, We ſay again y'are ſawcy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mazares.
sp.l: How durſt you bee ſo inſolent?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have deſerv'd Sir better language from you.
My anger is too ſtrong for my Obedience,
And will have th' upper hand. I come
To claim your Royall word—I am Cleander Sir,
Whoſe hand did ſeat the Crown upon your head Sir.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Provoke us not.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Good my Lord for your owne ſafety.
You ſee the King is mov'd.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Mov'd! By heaven i'l move him worſe, tell me I'm Inſolent.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: And we ſhall puniſh it, if you go not the ſooner.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I will not hence, and you ſhall hear me.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Go, y'are impudent.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Am I ſo Sir?
You did not tell me ſo, when I did waſte
Whole Nights, and ſpent my Spirits, to ſeduce
The People t • your Party, and loſt my blood
To ſerve you. I was not then—

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Stir not in me
An Anger that will ſhake thee.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Whoſe head, whoſe heart, whoſe hand appear'd till mine,
To make you what you are?

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: If we be King, Sir you ſhall feel there is
A power belonging to't. Wher's our Guard?
Take him away.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: I beſeech your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Effeminate Lord, I ſcorn to own a life
At thy Petitioning. Tyrant do thy worſt.
Is this the reward for all my ſervices—
Sit with your crew of Vaulters, and Contrive
To turn your Cittadels to dauncing ſchools
Or Stews fit for your purpoſe, till the Souldiery
Like to a ſudden Tempeſt ſcour your follies,
And whip you to Repentance.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes I ſhall go—Ungratefull Prince,
May all thy Brothers—

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Stop's mouth—away with him.
So we are rid of th' Screech Owle, did you e'r hear
Spleen better vented; All the Phyſicians of Palermo could not diſcover his diſeaſe better than he has don't himſelf.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And were I as your Majeſty, I'd cure him
By th'head for't.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: 'Tis not ſafe yet, but if this
Tame him not,
We ſhall fly higher,

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: The Serpent ſpet at me too.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Wee'l have the venom from him or his life for't.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Hee has a Daughter of that Beauty, would thaw a Stoick's boſome,
She carries the Quinteſsence of Youth about her.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Art thou acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Though I am not, I want not Confidence,
If that may ſerve your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Is ſhe compos'd for Mirth?

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: She bears a fame for Vertue.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: What ſhould we do with her then? ſhe is no Match for us.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: If your Majeſty have a Minde to her
I'l batter all her Vertues with your Glories;
And 'leſs an Hoaſt of Angels come to Guard her,
She ſhall not paſs my purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: When you Storm her let not a Repulſe or two
Make you draw off your Siege, the third Aſſault
Conſtrains her to Surrender.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: I am not my Lord
To learn the Art of Courtſhip, I have more
Deſignes than one upon her.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: We do like
The Law Lycurgus made, and will Ordain
The like amongſt us; why ſhould Youth be Curtail'd
Of that delight Nature intended it?
Mens Wives ſhall have the liberty to chooſe
A friend to play the Husbands part ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Does your Majeſty intend to Marry?

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Marriage is but a Church Diviſe, that would
Prefer ſobriety amongſt the Vertues,
A ſtale unſavoury thing; when as Variety
Gives life to every Senſe, and doth beget
An Appetite, when tother ſmothers it.
Adulanter try thy Skill, We ſhall reward it.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: I warrant ſhe's your Majeſties.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Come Philiſtus,
Wee'l bring thee on thy way, and leſt Miſſellus
Should prove ſtiffe Neck'd, and not yield his Obedience
To our Commands, our Generall ſhal ſend
With thee 5000. men to force Admittance.
Leontium, Tyche and Neapolis
Stand faſt to us, and will aſſiſt you if
The Siracuſians ſhould ſtand out.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Your Majeſty does enrich me with your Bounty.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Adulanter, We ſhall finde imployment worthy
Thy liking in Palermo; We will have
Thee neer us.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Your Highneſs Vaſſall.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: 'Tis fit,
Royality ſhould maintain them which uphold it.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: He is my Kiug, his Brother's death hath made
His Title good, and I muſt bring my heart
Down to Obedience.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Then you begin to cool.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I'm not Convinc'd in Conſcience that 'tis lawfull
T'oppoſe the power now o'r us, ſince the hand
Of Heaven is in't, whoſe high Decrees we ought not
To queſtion or diſpute.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: A happy Morning
Toth' Noble Lord Archias.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: The like to your Honours.
You heard the news?

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: What is't my Lord?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Philiſtus is made Provinciall of Vallis de Noto.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: How likes Cleander it?

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: He's otherwiſe Provided for, Committed
Upon diſpleaſure Mazares has ta'ne againſt him.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: That's news indeed.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: What Cleander, the Magazine of Policy,
Is he blown up? Mazar • s only Atlas
That ſhoulder'd him into the Throne.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: This is ſome State Gin, ſome trick Politick.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Beleev't 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Epe.
sp.l: How can Mazares be without him?

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Oh my Lord,
Mazares us'd Cleander as the Lame
Do their ſupporting Crutches, that's no longer
Than as they need 'em; when that they are able
To walk alore, they caſt 'em from 'em.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I'm glad on't with all my heart.
Mazares never Acted a thing as yet
So neer Commendable juſtice, Fair Aſtrea
May give it a juſt Plaudit.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: But Conſider,
If ſuch who have ventur'd their part of Heaven
To do him ſervice, are not free from's Tyranny,
Where reſts our ſafety?

sp.speaker: Epe.
sp.l: It is high injuſtice
So to reward him.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: In the ſurvey of Politickes,
Doſt find a Traytor otherwiſe rewarded?
Stands it with thy Diſcretion, to let looſe
A Tyger, when th'aſt mov'd him into Anger?
No, 'tis a way both ſafe and full of Juſtice
To Chain ſuch Danger up; had he done otherwiſe,
He had bin fitter rather to have rul'd
A Sheephook than a Scepter.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Come you are too bitter,
Think on Cleander's Age, and lend your aid.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: He ſhould have known more vertue in his Youth,
And then his Age had now bin Tempeſt proof.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: For my ſake good my Lord, and for his Daughters.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I, now my Lord you ſpeak, you are concern'd in't.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Your own, and all our freedoms are concern'd in't.
Shall we pay Duty and Obedience
To him, who does inſtruct us to Rebell
By his own Preſident? are we to learn
How he Obtain'd the Scepter? or want we Senſe
To feel how he imploies it? was it not
His own inſinuating Tenet to
The People, ('gainſt his Brother,) That the Vertue
And Juſtice of the Prince were th' onely Bonds
That bound the People to him, and when he
Should violate either, they were ty'd no longer?
Are we not Freemen then?

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Highly requiſite.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Where is the Common Right?
Our Juſt Inheritance? bought with the blood
Of our Indulgent Anceſtors? whoſe Valour
Bounded the Royall Power ſo, it durſt not
Spread beyond th' Acts of Piety and Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: See what Love, and Women can do!

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: My Lord Archbiſhop you are happily come
To Contribute your advice.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: My honour'd Lords,
The ſafety of your Perſons frees my Soul
That lately was a Slave to fear, and Jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I Churchman, 'twas your Feares, and Jealouſies,
Heav'd firſt at our foundation. Cicily had bin
Cleer from infection, had not your hot lungs
Spet the Contagion. It was you gave Reines
To the Licentious People, that Like Negroes
Shot their envenom'd Darts at th' Raies of Majeſty,
Whoſe carefull heat did warm e'm.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: You miſtake,
Wee aim'd at no ſuch thing, but to diſcharge
Our Duties to our Country.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: And y'ave prov'd
The moſt undutifull'ſt of all her Children.
And finding now the ends of your Ambition
Of being Cardinall is cleer laid open,
By which your Pride is like to be Obſcur'd,
You do begin to belch forth freſh Sedition,
And Create new Diſtempers, 'cauſe Mazares
Will not do what you'd have him.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: I come not Sir
To bandy words, the World knowes what I did
Was in Relation to the Churches Peace,
How e'r you term it; But ſo full of Poyſon
I find the Gilded Pils of his Profeſſions,
That plainly I muſt tell you without fear,
I heartily do wiſh thoſe hands that were
Imploy'd to Seat him o'r us, had bin us'd
To put him in his Grave.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Or bin lop'd off
Before they had Contracted ſuch an ill
Upon our Countrey:

sp.speaker: Epe.
sp.l: Ther's no time too late
To lanch the Ulcer and give eaſe unto
The groaning People, if my Lord Agathecles
Will call to Mind his death, that whets the Inſtrument,
Whoſe Precious Memory will give life to all
Our undertakings.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Come, my Lord, I'l have
The Biſhop and you reconcil'd. Wee'l to
Cleanders houſe, where the poor Lady Mourns
Her Fathers Abſence, there we will Conſult
On ſome way to Obtain his and our Freedoms.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Let not the Church-man be in it, and then
Doubt not but we ſhal make all right agen.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: This is her walk, I hope you doe not faint
At the Deſign, now 'tis ſo neer attempting

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: Yes I warrant you, as though ſhe were the firſt Wench we have had Occaſion to make uſe of.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Why what do you take us to be? Milkſops, I tel you Sir, we are Gentlemen in the firſt place, Souldiers in the ſecond, and men in the laſt place.

sp.speaker: Adulan.
sp.l: Good reaſon the laſt ſhould take place of the firſt then; but ſtay,
Yonders the Bird for which we wait, I'l try
If ſhe will come to hand, if not, your Net
Shall nooſe her into Tameneſs—ſtand cloſe.
Hail Madam, Heaven's Epitome, on whoſe
Bleſt ſmiles the happineſſe of Kings depend,
Pleaſure and health attend you.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: I thank you Sir,
But here it is unſeaſonable where ſorrow
Has it's Predominance.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: I bring you Comfort,
If you but pleaſe to honour the Addreſs
With kind Acceptance.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: Has my Ruthleſſe fortune
More Miſeries to heap on me, that ſhe
Preſents me with ſuch ſhadows of her favour?

sp.speaker: Adula.
sp.l: The King, to whom your Father's life is forfeit,
Throws both it, and his own into your lap
If you will be ſo wiſe as to receive 'em.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: Could I expreſs a thankfulneſs beyond
The Duty that I owe 'n my Prayers for him,
It ſhould fly to him, pray be pleas'd to teach me
The way to it.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Fame has bin buſie
In giving to the King an Eſtimat
Of your Perfections, whoſe high Value fils
Th' Exchequor of his Breaſt, and 'tis your Love
Muſt free the Heart your Bounty has ſubdu'd.

sp.speaker: H •• m.
sp.l: I'm ignorant of your meaning.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: To be his Miſtres.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: Or in plainer Terms, which ſhews the truth on't,
To be his Whore.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Fy; that is too Common;
Conſider Madam, he that Courts you is
Your King, who may Compell where he intreats,
And you will forfeit your Allegiance if
You ſhould deny him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: To the Gods I ſhould,
Durſt I preſume to Grant it; if my Father
Muſt not enjoy his life, but on the Terms
Of my diſhonour, th'duty that I ow
To Heaven and Goodneſs will Implead againſt
The Bonds of Nature, which can Challenge but
The life it gave, and that I'l offer up
To Ranſome his.

sp.speaker: Adulan.
sp.l: That will not ſerve the turn,
You muſt to Court.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: I'l firſt go to my grave.

sp.speaker: Adu.
sp.l: Nay then adue Complement, and to your buſineſſe fellows.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Adu.
sp.l: To hide your Bluſhes Madam.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Help, help, help.

div.stage: They throw a ſilk bag over her, ſhee ſtrives with them, they ſtop her mouth with a Glove, and bind her hands and feet.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Stop her mouth.

div.stage: Enter Agathocles, Archias, Epecides, and Archbiſhop.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I am o'rcome in Reaſon, and do Crave
Your Lordſhips pardon.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: My Lord you have my Heart
At your diſpoſing.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: This Reconcilement's handſome.

sp.speaker: Adu.
sp.l: So, the field's our own, take up your Bag and Baggage, March fair and ſoftly,
When wee come to Court wee'l ſhare the Booty.
sp.stage: As they are carrying her away they meet the Lords, they caſt her down and run back.
sp.l: A Plague upon't, down with your load, and make an Honourable Retreat.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: 'Twas Adulanter—what's this, It moves,
sp.stage: Ʋnbinds her, takes the Glove out of her mouth.
sp.l: Your help my Lords,—Ah! 'tis Harmonia.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: What Monſtrous Stratagem had they upon her?

sp.speaker: Harmo.
sp.l: Air is a Bleſſing, oh, let me have more on't.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Dear Madam ſpeak your wrongs, and wee will right you,
If the beſt blood in Cicily can do't.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: My life, and Honour, (far more precious) were
Deſign'd for Slaughter.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: How Madam! by whom?

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: By him who, ſhould protect the Innocent,
The Lawleſs King; whoſe Cauſeleſs wrath upon
My Father, nothing could appeaſe unleſs.
I made ſale of my Vertue, and my Youth
To ſatisfie his Luſt,

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Whoſe fire wee'l quench
With his own blood; be confident Harmonia
Thy Father ſhall outlive his Power and Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: If we take not this edge off, We ſhall have
Our Wives and Daughters made the Subjects of
Our ſcorn and ſhame, and be ſqueek'd out in Ballads
For honourable Cuckolds, Princely Panders.
Whoſe Soul is ſo beſotted to his fear
He can contract it to a Minutes Patience?

sp.speaker: Archbi.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: Nor I; ſure he does think the Gods
Are all aſleep, or have forgot to puniſh.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Hence Patience, thou Fools vertue;
I'l ſhake off
Thy Coldneſs, with the Witchcraft of Obedience,
Who have ſo long kept me in Cels of Slavery
I could not ſee the Glory of my Freedom.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Wee'l kindle all our Vigour • t thy flame,
And teach our knees to Pay their homage to
No Power but thine; My Lords if that wee be
All of one Minde, cry, long live Archias.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: I wait not for that Dignity beleeve me,
All my Ambition is to free this Lady
From th' gaſtly feares that haunt her, and give liberty
Unto her happineſs, by her Fathers Freedome.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Which to Atchieve (my Lord) receive the Power
Heaven and We offer you; Monreall is
Your own already.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: And the Agrigentines
Proclame you in my Voice their lawfull King.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: And all the Citizens in Palermo ſpeak
The like in me—Long live Archias.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live Archias.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: My Lords forbear, Mazares lives.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Abhorred of the Gods, and 'tis but Juſtice
To take him off.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Heaven fit me for the truſt
You a throw on me, and now Harmonia,
Sweet Empreſs of my Soul, receive thy Archias,
Who muſt not know a Joy but what thou ſhar'ſt of;
Cleander free'd, Wee ſhall requeſt your hand,
To joyn our hearts, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Where Vertue keeps
Her Court, the Gods are Gueſts; your
Choice is Heavenly.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: I was ev'n now the wretched'ſt of all living,
And now am lifted to a happineſs
That Queens would kneel to purchaſe—
My Dear Lord.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: My Heaven on Earth.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Think on your Bus'neſs Sir,
The perfecting of that gives length unto
Your Amorous Daies.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Whoſe flouriſhing we wiſh.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: My Lords, my thanks, with your advice I move,
No Engine is ſo pow'rfull as your love.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: The fineſt coming'ſt Lady that your Highneſs
Could wiſh to meet withall, and rarely handſome.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: And did accept our proffer?

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: As Greedily
As Bees ſuck ſweetneſs from the fragrant Stock
Of Flora's Early bounty.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: I'm all flame,
By Heaven not one of them ſhall ſcape my fury.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Nay, I think I had like to have
Maul'd two of them,
Had not the Church man with his Clublaw Precepts
Beat down my Reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Damb his Daubing,
Hee is that Knack, Religous-Mountebanck,
A Box of frenzied-zeal which he applies
On all Occaſions, to all ſorts of ſores,
And wracks the Patient with more fear and Torment
Than Hell it ſelf can put him to.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: A Coat
He weares that has bin turn'd ſeven times.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Which wee will turn o'r's Eares, and then turn them
Oppoſe our Pleaſure; Hee, and all the reſt
Of his Confederates ſhall know we wear
Our Crown not for a Cipher, and our Scepter
Shall prove a ſcourge to them; they have awak'd
A fury that no Prayers can allay.
Haſte to the Governour Icelis, tell him
It is our will Cleander's Spirit leave
The World with ſpeed and privacy. Proclame
Our Cockbrain'd Couſen, and the Piebal'd Church-man,
Agathocles and Epecides Trayters;
And ſuch as ſhall take them five thouſand Talents.
So violent I grow in my deſire,
I muſt enjoy it or ſet all on fire.

div.head: ACT 3. SCE. 1.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: PUrſu'd by my bad Fate, whoſe Cruelty
I knew would not admit of any Mean
Should it once ſeize on me, I ſtruck my ſelf
Into Diſguiſe, by whoſe Obſcurity
I came to Tyche, there, gave out my hand
Had kill'd Evander, at which, ſome that were
My Enemies gave tokens of their Sorrow;
Others, who thought their Riſing not ſecure
'Leſs by my Irrecoverable fall,
Highly applauded me. At laſt a Remnant
Of my poor friends, Reſolv'd to pay their laſt
Service unto my Memory, though with
The loſs of their Eſtates and lives, did lay
Plots to deſtroy me as the horrid Murtherer,
And I, not daring to open my ſelf
To them, for fear I ſhould let in the fury
Of my ſtern Adverſaries, did ſteal away
With the Nights ſilence.

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: Though the beginning of
This Story melts my Soul, Yet Providence
Is ſeen in th' winding up, which did direct
Your Highneſs hither, where y'are as ſecure
From danger as your thoughts are in your Boſome.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: We doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: You dead, what can Mazares
Pretend to keep his Armies up? this, I'l
Poſſeſs the People with, and ſtir them to
Propoſe their ſtreight disbanding, which if Granted,
The Courſe of Fate is turn'd, and he left Naked,
And ſhelterleſs from any Storm may happen.
On tother ſide if he denies it, then
Th'incenſed People like a ſudden Earthquake
Removes him, were his Pride more Mountanous
Than are his Vices Monſtrous; thus on all ſides
I'l hem him in, ſo he ſhall know no way
To ſcape your Vengeance; be but pleas'd to ſuffer
Under this Clowd awhile, and you'l appear
More glorious to your Peoples eyes and hearts,
When time preſents a fitneſs for diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thou art our faithfull Counſellor, and We
Next to the Gods do ow our Self to thee.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: We are not far from Syracuſe, this Paſſage
Is the direct line to't, as the Map ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Thimi.
sp.l: My Lord, I hope your Honor will not ſhew
Your ſelf ſo much a Stranger to Deſignes
Of War, as to give them th' advantage of
A Parley, but ruſh ſuddenly upon them,
And like a Torrent wee'l bear all before us,
Ther's Souldier in't.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: It is too raſh advice
And muſt be ſlighted; Miſſellus is a Perſon
That Roughneſs will not work upon.

sp.speaker: Thim.
sp.l: My Lord,
He is no Coward, and his Honor's link'd
Unto his life, he that will ſeek the one,
Muſt venture for the other, or loſe both.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: If my deſires effect but what they aim at,
I care not when, or how, 'tis purchaſed.
Haſte you with the Kings Letter to Miſſellus,
Tell him 'tis my deſire to keep the League
Of friendſhip 'twixt us, and without a buſſle,
Which may let forth ſome blood, have him Surrender;
Tell him, 'tis no diſpleaſure that the King
Has tane againſt him, that occaſions his,
But to give eaſe unto his Age, and draw
Him neerer him at Court, where he ſhall find
The ſervice of his Youth, in's latter daies
Crown'd with a peacefull Lawrel, and content
Ad length unto his yeers.

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.l: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Thimiſtius, March fair and ſoftly, we ſhall be
Too ſoon upon e'm els; this cannot but
Inſinuate a faith into him, to
Give way to my Admittance, ſince the offer
Carries ſo full a ſenſe of fairneſs in't.

sp.speaker: Thim.
sp.l: My Lord, hee's not to learn this Principle,
Where Princes call back Honors done, the life
Is the next thing in Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Let the Fates
Contrive their worſt againſt it, if Antanter
Bring us ſupplies from the Provinciall
Of Mona, we will fire it but wee'l have it.

sp.speaker: Thimſt.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, the Craft's in th' Catching.

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: Doſt come to dare me Fellow?

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.l: I conceive
With favour of your Excellence, the Terms
Are very Civill, and no danger in e'm.

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: I ſhall reward his Subtle Modeſty
If I but get him here, as I will you
The worthy Meſſenger, take's head off.

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.l: You dare not?

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: Thou art miſtaken friend; away with him.
Oh that I could with as much eaſe deſtroy
All th'barbarous Enemies of my wronged Soveraign.
Make ſtrong the Gates and Walls, and let the Fort
Hexapile be ſtoutly Mann'd, wee'l be
Prepar'd to whip the Boy and's Company.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: The Gates are ſhut againſt us.

sp.speaker: Thim.
sp.l: What think you now on't?

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Beat a Parley.
sp.stage: The head of Philander is thrown over the Wall.
sp.l: How's this? Philanders head?

sp.speaker: Thimi.
sp.l: Which you might have preſerv'd upon his ſhoulders,
Had you given but regard unto my Counſell.
But you are Lordly-wiſe, and cauſe you can
Batter a Ladies fort with your fine Rhetorick,
You think the Town's your own, and men are bound
To bend unto your Complement, or truſt
The Glaſs of your deceipt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis fine, affronted
By Greaſie Buffe and Bisket.

sp.speaker: Thim.
sp.l: Some ſtrong Water
To keep the thing from fainting, poor Young Man,
How pule he looks upon't.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Take thy reward.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Our Colonell ſlain.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Were there more living of his ſawcy Nature
I'd ſend them after him; Antanter what
Saies the Provinciall?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Hee'l do nothing Sir
Without a Warrant from the King, hee ſaies
He does beleeve there will bee no ſuch need,
Miſsellus will reſign upon fair Terms.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: But you ſee how it is?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do indeed,
And ſorrow that I ſee't—How came Thimiſtius
By this his death?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: That Lord's hand did it.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Come, we will venture with the Men we have
To ſcale the walls.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We will not ſcale Sir.

sp.speaker: Philiſt.
sp.l: So,
You will not, very good; do you ſee this head Sir?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: And that body too Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let me have better Language or by Heaven
I'l make you as tame as theſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You cannot Sir.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: 'Tis not all
The ſtrength you have in Feather or Perfume
Can fright me Sir; Your Amber Bracelets carry
Not half the Terror of Chain'd ſhot, nor is
Your Title Lord a Bulwark to defend you.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Y'are a Raſcall.
Come Souldiers March with me.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Not a Man ſtir,
Ther's ſatisfaction to be given for
The life of that brave Man, which I will have
Or pay my own.

sp.speaker: Soula.
sp.l: Gallant Major.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I ſhall not ſpare to give you Sir your due.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: I'le not be backward in rewarding it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You are Pot-valiant (Sir) it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Anta,
sp.l: 'Tis paſt the Art of Man to make you ſo;
I am a Souldier Sir.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: And muſt be beat
Into Civility, I'l make you know
There is a difference 'twixt us.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: True indeed,
You can out-talke me.
How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You ſhall know by and by Sir—
I am loſt.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Farewell thou Tyrant over Womans fleſh.
Take up Thimiſtius body, it ſhall have
An honourable buriall, as for his
Let it remain a ſport for th'Siracuſians.
The King I know will run beſides himſelf
To hear on's Minions loſs, but you I hope,
My friends and fellow Souldiers, will wade with me
Through all the Lakes of danger.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Wee'l never leave you.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Bravely reſolv'd, and I will die with you.

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: Th'are march'd away; what's here Philiſtus body,
Our late Competitor? Why here's revenge
Strangely effected! See the fate of Traytors!
How wonderfully Heaven does bring about
Their Puniſhment! that like to Caniballs
The one doth eat the other; bring it in;
My hate ends with his Life, and now my Charity,
Though he deſerv'd it not, will give him buriall.

div.stage: Archias, Agathocles, Epecides Cleander, Icetis, paſs over the Stage. The People follow, crying an Archias, an Archias, an Archias.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Their Envy is Invincible, and the People
Time's Shittle-cocks) do bring unto your Gates
The hidious Shape of danger.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: My deceipt
Shall Rock that Monſter into ſleep, had it
More eyes than Argos.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: 'Tis impoſſible,
The Agrigentines have thrown off Obedience;
Monreall is revolted; All your Caſtles
And ſtrongs holds in Palermo are deliver'd
Into their hands; the Magiſtrates joyn with them.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Go uſe thy beſt Endeavours Adulanter
T' appeaſe the People, turn right Courtier, promiſe,
And wee'l perform at Leaſure.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Your Highneſs
I hope is not in Earneſt; I go amongſt 'em!
Have you a Mind to have my Braines beat out?
I am your Pimp they ſay, (Sir,) am ſo hated,
The very Boys throw Turap tops at me.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Alas poor Adulanter, we wi'l blow
This Storme away ne'r fear it, Let our Guard
Be doubled, till we can ſend t' Her mocrates
To bring his Forces hither: If the Traytors
Come not too ſuddenly upon us, We
Will turn the poyſon'd Darts they'd throw at us
'Gainſt their own Boſomes, They do play with fire
Till it Conſume 'em.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: They like Moales have work'd
In darkneſs all this while, to ſet the Kingdome
In ſuch a flame that might both Periſh you
And all your friends.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Fire ſooner may diſſolve
The Adamant, the Parched Negroes ſtrike
Through th' Battlements of Heaven. Wee are above
The reach of Malice, Fortune is Oblieg'd
To wait upon our Merit, and our Influence
Can in a breath diſpierce their proud Deſignes,
As Winds diveſt the Trees of Leaves. Let fear
Dwell among Fooles 't ſhall have no Harbour here.

div.stage: Enter Archias, Archbiſhop, Agathocles, Epecides, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Leave it to me, I'l do the buſineſs Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: 'Tis not diſcretion to expoſe your Perſon
So unconcern'd in this; 'tis we, the People,
Whoſe wrongs infer the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Which I muſt manage.
Y'ave made me your Protector, and Revenger,
Which I'l perform, did Gloomy Magick Guard him;
Or were he wrapt in Air, or hid in ſome
Dark Cavern of the Earth, my Heart grown big
Like Dire Revenging Thunder would make through
The bodies of them both to find him out.

sp.speaker: Agathoc.
sp.l: Our lives ſhall wait on yours through dangers mouth.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: An Archias, an Archias.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: They have ſurpriz'd the Guards, and are upon us.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Haſte to the Winner, leave us to our Fortune,
Provide for thy own ſafety, We are arm'd
With Reſolution to o'rcome the worſt
The Fates can throw upon us; leave us, leaev us.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: They'l hang me Sir, and I've no
Mind at this time
To ſuch a death.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Trifle not away
The time, they will not; go, leave us.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Well, If I chance to ſwing, pray
Heaven I may
Have Heart enough to bear it.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Injurious Fate, for all the pride thou tak'ſt
In my deſtruction thus I will imbrace thee.
sp.stage: Takes the ſword off the Table, kiſſes it.
sp.l: Miſchiefes like waves tumble o'r one another,
To beat themſelves upon me, and th'are welcome;
This paſſes me through all. Poor ignorant ſoules
That ſtart at Death, and think him terrible!
His ſhape appears to me worthy the Courting;
And like my Friend I kiſſe him; on this Point
He ſhewes himſelf moſt lovely, deck'd with all
The Ornaments of honour Fame can give him.
Thus I ſalute thee, thus again I greet thee,
And thus I offer up a heart unto thee:
A heart, thy Terror cannot tame, 'tis Love
Of thy ſweet fellowſhip o'rcomes me, not
A fear to meet thee, that, my Soul diſdaines.
Mazares dwell not on delaies, be high
In thy Reſolves, as thou haſt liv'd ſo die.
Oh, I have prevented you.

div.stage: Enter Archias, Archbiſhop, Agathocles, Epecides, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: And I
Envy thy death in that I loſe
The glory of ſaving of thy life.

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Which muſt have laſted
But Pageant-like two daies upon your Triumphs,
And my ſhame bin perpetuall.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Do you find
Any remorſe within you? does the wrongs
Y'ave offer'd to the Gods in pulling down
Their Temples and their Altars work upon you
Any ſhew of repentance?

sp.speaker: Maza.
sp.l: Thou Church-Glow-worm,
Who doſt pretend a heat of Zeal, yet art
Colder than th'Alpes in Charity, if prov'd,
My Enmity to thee gives ſtrength unto me,
And I could—but ô I fail, this my death
Shall prove a Monument to my Glory—Farewell.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Here is another of the crew.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Hang him up.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.p: Who me Sir? I ne'r dreamt of ill againſt you, have pray'd as heartily for you as for any Man living; for I may ſpeak a proud word, I never prayed in my life. I hope my mother brought me up better than ſo, to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Let me beſeech your pardon for him, alas
He is not worth your Juſtice, and may prove
Uſefull hereafter—to me

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Noble Father,
For ſo wee muſt bee taught to call you, you
Have greater power upon us than this Grant;
'Tis yours as ſoon as ask'd.

sp.speaker: Adula.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs the King.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Take up Mazares body, his rites over,
The next thing wee ſhall doe, is to perform
Our Vowes made to the Gods, and take Harmonia
Your Daughter to our Bed.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: And the next thing
That followes is thy death, I muſt be King.

div.head: ACT 4. SCE. 1.
div.stage: Enter Archias, Harmonis, Archbiſhop, Agathocles, Cleander, Epecides, Adulanter.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: VVEE'l have the Temples of the Gods repair'd,
And their neglected Altars ſmoak with S • crifices.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: A glorious Piece of Piety.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: The Citizens
Who for their Duty to Evander were
Baniſh'd by the late Tyrant, ſtraight call'd home;
And to Hermocrates with his Complices
Who did aſſiſt Mazares, a free Pardon.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: A bleſt beginning.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: We will have the burthen
The Kingdome now groanes under by the Souldierly
Be taken off.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: The Gods will dwell amongſt us.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: My Lords I ſhall endeavour to reduce
This rude and diſcompoſed Soile into
A Tempe of Delight, where ſweet Harmonia
Shall be the onely Queen.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: It will become me
To be but then your Servant.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Sweet thou knowſt
I am beneath thy Courtſhip, and the intereſt
I have in thee is holy.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: May you flouriſh
Together like the Plants the Sun gives life to.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Will your Highneſs
Think on Antanter?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Oh his Modeſty
Works much upon us, we could chide our ſelf
In that we have abus'd it, by neglect
Of his ſo juſt and reaſonable a ſute.
As for the other, his Competitor,
A black Cloud of Debauchneſs and leud Vices
Ecclips his Valour, and gives us Occaſion
To looke upon Antanter as more worthy
Of ſuch a Charge, whoſe Virtue is our Warrant.
Kings in beſtowing Favours ſhould bee nice,
And rather puniſh than Encourage Vice.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Adulanter.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Wilt tell me one thing, and bee juſt.

sp.speaker: Adula.
sp.l: Rip up my heart my Lord, if I diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How ſtands thy affection to this King?

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: As clear as—

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Mine is not, be free, I love thee,
And thou haſt found I do.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: I have indeed,
I ow my life unto you, you may take it,
For that's the thing you aim at.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Th'art deceiv'd,
'Twill benefit me nothing; come, I know
Thou canſt not love him, thou haſt loſt a Maſter
As far beyond him, as pure Subſtance is
Beyond Corruptible; and though he did
Me ſome ill offices, his Memory is
Still dear unto me.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: By all the Gods I lie not, and to be
More plain with thee, I could wiſh Archias
Were ready for the Earth.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: If that your Lordſhip
Be reall, I would it were no worſe.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: If he were dead, my Daughter I would Govern,
And thou ſhouldſt govern me.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Oh fie, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I do proteſt wee would divide the Kingdome
Betwixt us, ſhe (poor thing) would think it happineſs
Enough for her to eat, ſit, and be quiet:
Whereas the Mannaging of high affairs
Should paſſe through us, through us Adulanter.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Whoſe knee dares own a ſtiffeneſs? whoſe Obeyſance
To Adulanter dare be wanting? when
Thou Frown'ſt, who dares but trembble?

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: When ſuch a thing ſhall come to paſs quoth a—

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Do'ſt make a queſtion on't, when now it lies
Within thy power to Compaſs.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: How, in mine?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Art thou not my by meanes rais'd neer his Perſon?
One of the Bed-chamber? how eaſie 'tis
To cut is throat.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: The ſight of my own blood,
Has ever bin a Terror to me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: True,
That's Naturall, and yet no Courage wanting
To draw a Sea of blood from any other;
The Colour is moſt precious for the ſight,
And ſweetly Cordiall to the Man that taſts it.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Nay I confeſs I'd rather ſee of th' two
Anothers blood than mine.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Tis juſtly ſpoken.
Would'ſt thou be King alone?

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Hum—I care not much.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be ſo, be but thy ſelf, and ſhew
Thy Courage in this Enterpriſe: I'l Marry
Thee to my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Shee's a pretty thing,
By Heaven I ſhall be damn'd for her.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I'd rather
Thou ſhould'ſt poſſeſs her than the Fool that has her;
And I, thy fellow ſervant once, will then
Become thy humbleſt ſervant, truly faithfull.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: You puffe me up Sir, tell me how I ſhall
Contain my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Not within any limit
Leſs than a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: How ſhall I obtain it?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why, as you'd kiſs your hand, to kill the King;
It is but making the Guard Drunk, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: And I'm as good at that as any living;
My Lord I will be drunk too boot, for then
I have moſt Courage.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Back'd with Night and ſilence
You cannot want it; when you have done the Deed
Strike towards the Back ſtairs, there I will wait you,
And Shelter you a while, 'till the bright Morn
Salutes your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: My Lord, 'tis done;
I am as Mad as a March hare upon't,
Methinks I have him here, and there allready,
You will hear more to morrow.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Silly Aſs,
That only art imploid to carry me
Unto my bliſs, thy ſelf unto deſtruction;
Hee's held an Animall has no Deceit
In theſe times to make his own Fortunes Great.

div.stage: Enter Archias, Harmonia, Archbiſhop, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Archbi.
sp.l: Heaven and good Angels guard you both.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Good reſt
To you my Lord.

sp.speaker: 1 Guard.
sp.l: Lights for the Lord Archbiſhop.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.l: Did the King call for me?

sp.speaker: 2 Guard.
sp.l: Not in our hearing.

sp.speaker: Adul.
sp.p: Come, prais'd be Heaven there is no danger lurking, what need we wait? 'tis better for the ſtate of our bodies to fall down into the Wine ſeller, and there bid defiance to the Devill and all's works.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: A Match, a match.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: The Mask did keep the King up longer than
His uſuall time.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: It was a handſome thing,
And well perform'd, all happineſs wait on you.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: Peace keep with your thoughts my Lord, Good night.

sp.speaker: Attend.
sp.l: Lights there.

sp.speaker: Adula.
sp.l: I have encountred with moſt of the Wines
In the Kings Seller to beget me Courage,
Yet I'm as Cold to't as a Cowcumer
I was not made for fighting, one loud ſnort
Deſtroyes me and my Enterpriſe: 'Tis Dark
As is the Act I go about; were't light
I ſhould not have the heart to kill a Pig.
I muſt turn on my left hand (when 'tis done)
To the back ſtairs, where there is a Trap-door
That will receive me. I do not like
Theſe backward doings, pray Heaven I be not
Tranſported ſo with fear I do miſtake
My right hand for my left, and ſo be trapt.
I cannot ſay in ſober ſadneſs—but with your leave Sir;
Hee's faſt, yet dreams not on't, now! that one blow
May do't! I dare not ſtand the ſecond—

div.stage: Kiſs Harmonia, and runs to the Trap door where he fals and breaks his neck.

sp.speaker: Harm.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: What diſturbs thee ſweet, ſpeak to me,
Oh, her breaſts are cold as ſnow-balls,
She grows ſtiffe. Lights there—wher's our Guard?
No Attendants, not one Man—
sp.stage: Enter Agathocles, Epecides, in their Night-gowns, and Lights.
sp.l: Hear me, are you all—

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: The King's diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: How fares your Highneſs?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Bring your lights this way—Ah!
The Bed ſwims in a Sea of Blood—Harmonia.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: The Queen is Murther'd.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The King Murther'd! how!

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Look here Cleander, her's a ſight—my Senſes
Wander I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Clean,
sp.l: How! my Daughter
Harmonia the Eſſence of my life.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Can no man find the Murth'rer, wher's the Guard?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Dead drunk in th' Wine-ſeller.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: This is the Murtherer, then ſeek no farther;
I will have juſtice, oh my curſed Fate.

sp.speaker: Epcci.
sp.l: How's Griefe tranſports him.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Can you blame him?
H'has loſt a Daughter this Age cannot Parallel.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: The Murtherer not found yet?
This does appear like ſuch a Monſter.
His hire is paid, his Neck is broke.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: 'Tis Adulanter, where found you him?

sp.p: The Trap door neer the back ſtairs we found open, which has not bin theſe ten yeers before, and we ſuſpecting ſearch'd the place and found him.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: And is he found? let him be Carbonadod,
To Breakfaſt his Confederate the Devill.
Or Pickle him in boyling Lead to get
The Fiend a ſtomach; Oh you Gods, you Devils,
Heaven, Hell, I will call all of you to queſtion.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let's follow him with Circumſpective care,
This is the firſt ſtep to the Hill, Diſpair.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt no longer inſult o'r my faculties
Unprofitable Griefe; I'm not Deſign'd
To end my daies with thee, but muſt unload
My ſelf of thy dull burthen; were the whole
Stock of Woman loſt in my Harmonia,
'T ſhould not exact or draw a tear from me.
Shall I retreat now, that have Charg'd ſo fairely
At th'boſome of a King? no, on Cleander,
Perfect thy work, diſ-ſeat him, make thy ſelf
Lord of his fortunes, by thy Glorious Conqueſt.
My Reſolution's fixt as is the Center,
Which Fate cannot remove; King thou muſt down,
Two heads cannot be impal'd within one Crown.
But to my former ſhape; theſe are Courtſpies,
I muſt not truſt e'm. Good health to your Lordſhips,
You now do ſhew the ſweetneſs of your natures,
In time of heavineſs, ther's vertue in A Viſit.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Would ours might bring you Comfort.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: The King is ſo infected with his ſorrow,
Advice is loſt to cure him. All his Studdy
Is to preſerve the Memory of your Daughter,
Which 'cauſe he will not loſe, he makes her ſhadow
His Idoll, to the which he offers up
His Morn and Night Oblations.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How ſhould I
Behave my ſelfe then? my Griefe ſhould as far
Exceed his, as my loſs tranſcended his.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: Your loſs was great.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Great do you tell me! Great!

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: I cannot think the ill was meant to her,
Rather unto the King.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: The Guard
Upon Examination ſaid that Adulanter
Was drunk when he left them, but what—

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Pray tell me no more on't, 'tis not pleaſing, I may be quiet
In my own houſe I hope.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: We came not Sir
With an intent to raiſe your Anger, but
'To allay your ſorrow with our beſt advice.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You may go home and adviſe upon't; tell me of comfort, and advice?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord you may take pet and hang your ſelf if you pleaſe, 'tis all one to us

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Teach me to tame a Tyger when his fierceneſs
Ranges for Prey, and forbids Oppoſition;
Empty the Ocean and fill it again;
To breath life into Clay—Tell me of Comfort?

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: Come let's leave him, alas 'tis his Torment
To hear her nam'd—We take our leaves my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why farewell you—ſo, they are gone,
I had no better way than to Rave them hence.
Oh, are you come Sir, why ſo long firſt?

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: Goud faith, gif I had rid the Deel and ſpult the weamb othe wund, I cud a mead na mare heaſt. Kym away Sir, what's your Wull an pleaſ your Honor?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: They ſay you have great skill.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.l: Very Muckle Sir; I ha not ben a Poles-Screamer this twenty yeers far naught.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I do not love the King.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.l: Reight weel Sir, nor I by my ſaw what wud you toll him Sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I would be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.l: Woll your Honor be a Hearſe or a Meare?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Away, I'd be quit of him.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: Aw Sir, your honor wud be quite au him! be me ſaw, ye fall, but whilke way me Loord an plaſe yoor honor?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I'd have him poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.l:
Peyſon'd! be me ſaw I kan dew
that brawly, I leard it fra Bough-wha-nan Sir.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: And hee was an excellent King-killer.
He has a Picture of my murther'd Daughter,
On which he paies his early and late kiſſes,
Not for the Love hee bears her Memory,
But to deceive Revenge.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.l: Aw Sir! ſhe fall buſs him deede a me ſaw,—woll
Yee ſhaw me toll her Sir.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I'm glad to ſee the ſpirit of a Scot
So reſolute, it ſtars not at the Murthering
Of the Fools Idoll, King.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Aw King Mon! dee'l aw me ſaw bet I, au me Countramen ha peyſon'd thra better Kingdoms as this, au gif I ſud noow for aw King the Deel au me faw lugg's.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou art a brave fellow, and 'tis pitty ſuch
Deſert ſhould ſuffer; come along with me.
When thou haſt done, I'l make an end of thee.

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: I thought it then high time to overtake
His Mounting-pride, and Levell 't with the Earth;
And not to let him grow more fruitfull in
His ſin, and overtopping Inſolency.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: It was a Deed Antanter that deſerves
To live in th' Mouth of Fame, that after Ages
From thence may learn not to fear bugbear-greatneſs.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.p: Thimiſtius body I gave buriall, and Left tothers to Miſelluſes diſpoſall.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: 'Twas no ſmall ſport to him, but it was ſtrange
Planetius ſhould deny Aſſiſtance to him.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: I do beleeve Miſſellus and he held
A Correſpondency, but for what end I cannot reach.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: He is not to be truſted;
If this diſtemper once would leave the King
Thou would'ſt not think't a Miracle to ſee
Me in Planetius Seate. Now Epecides
How fares the King?

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen, our hopes
That promiſed a Growing-happineſs
From his indulgent Beames, One Minute has
Deſtroi'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: How do you mean my Lord?

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: The King is poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: How Poyſon'd! Poyſon'd?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: There is a ſecret Devill lurks among us,
Who holds Intelligence with Hell to blaſt
Our Kingdomes Peace and Comfort; ſee, they come.

div.stage: Enter Archias in a Bed, Archbiſhop, Cleander, Phiſicians, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: The Flames of Aetna are not fierce to mine,
Each facultie conſpires my Torment; oh
I burn, I burn.

sp.speaker: Phiſi.
sp.l: Great Sir, be not an Enemy
Unto your Being, take this as—

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Away,
You may as well give Phiſick to the dead,
As to his Heart whoſe agony exceeds
The ſenſe of Eaſe; I am reſolv'd to take
No more of your vain helps; leave me I pray.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My moſt Gracious Souveraign,
I have a heart too weak to bear the burthen
Of ſo much Wo, your ſufferings bear me down
Beneath the hope of Comfort.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Spare thy Griefe;
Harmonia treads the Milkie way, and I
Muſt through this fire, be purifi'd to meet
Her and the Joyes ſhe brings me.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Does none hear
By whom, or how theſe Miſeries ſhould come?

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Trouble not your ſelf (my Lord)
I freely Pardon
And will reward the Doer, ſo declare it▪
For he has taken paines to ſend me to
The Place I ſo much long'd for; I do charge you
(If my laſt words may win Obedience from you)
Straight to Proclaim this; fain I would ſalute
Him e'r I die, that was ſo kind unto me.

sp.speaker: Archbi.
sp.l: Unheard of Charity.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: My Lord from ou
I have conceiv'd in Specie the joyes
I muſt receive hereafter; thoſe ſweet Odours
Perfume my Spirituall ſenſe, and ſtrengththen that,
Although my Temporall decay and periſh.

div.stage: Enter Servant with the Scotch Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Here is a Scotch Apothecary that confeſſes—

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Art thou the Villain?

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: Au the mickle Deul—god gin the King wud gi me bet een hauf ooer toll live bet I cud ſpeak—aw—Deeth thau limmer loone—aw, aw—

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: My Lord 'twas raſhly done, wee might have found
Where the ill vapour reſts begets theſe miſchiefes,
And who ſet him on work.

sp.speaker: Clea,
sp.l: The Devill, who els?
And he has paid him's wages.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Cleander.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: The King calls Sir▪

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: I feel my vitals fail me, Oh Cleander
I ſhall ſee my Harmonie, thy bleſt Daughter,
E'r fourty Minutes paſs, I muſt bequeath thee
A Legacy of Care, this drooping Kingdom.
My Lords I hope the love you ever bore me
(Though Heaven denies me time to Merit it)
Will now expreſs it ſelfe in the approving
Him I preſent to you, a dying Man
Who has no ends upon you, nor the Kingdom,
Farther than your perpetuall flouriſhing.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I beſeech your Grace,—alas—

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: You hear me Lords.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: We do Sir, and accept the choice
Y'ave made,
With more than willingneſs.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: You have not ſpoke for me.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: I am at reſt, farewell.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Hee's dead.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And I
His weeping Monument remains till Fate
Tranſlates my better part t' a better State.

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: Theſe are fine turning times, I wonder when
'Twill come to my turn to be King, I have
A Heart as fit, and large, and dare as far
Adventure for't as any, But the Fates
Of Souldiers ſerve to Promote others ends,
Which done, they do forget we e'r were friends.
