sp.speaker: Hippa.
sp.l: Your words ſound like the Oracle's, as full
Of truth, and plainer to the Intellect.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: How ſweet and freely Rome enjoy'd her ſelf,
'Till ſhe ſubmitted to the Power and pride
Of one mans Rule? Tell me what good did ever
Kings bring unto our Country, that wee might not
Have purchaſed without e'm? Ills they have
Almoſt incredible; Our Coffers emptied,
To fill their Treaſury, and maintain their Riot.

sp.speaker: Epe.
sp.l: And wedded to perpetuall Slavery.
For when one Tyrant falls another Riſes
From his Corrupted Loynes, that proves far worſe
Perhaps than did the former, So that wee
Muſt never hope for better, but be Arm'd
With Patience to endure the worſt.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Suppoſe
We would allow of Kingly Power, where is
The Man diſcended from that Race? Cleander
He was but one of us the other day;
And ſure we are not of ſo tame a brood,
But to think We deſerv't as well as he.
Why ſhould not you Icetis, or Hipparinus
Rule, or thou, Epecides, or my ſelf?
W'are of as good a Mould, and have as much
T'elate us, as his Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: Very right.
And have as great an Intereſt in the People
And Common-wealth; this of Neceſſity
Muſt breed Con • uſion 'mongſt us, this Example
Kindles in every Man deſire of Rule,
Which to Archieve, how perilous ſo e'r
Th' Attempt may prove, they'l leave no means unſought,
Till their irregular Senſe, ſpurning at Order,
Turns all into a Chaos.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Who can tell
But this Intruder was th' efficient Cauſe
Of his own Daughters ruin, and the Kings.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: It was a notable peece of Policy
To kill the Apothecary and prevent Confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Icet.
sp.l: What's your advice?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: To joyn with us,
And take th' Peoples Yoke off from the Tyranny
Of Kings hereafter.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: And to have our Countrey
Govern'd by three or ten, as did the Romans.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: Who ſhall continue but a Yeer in Power,
And then ſucceſſive Pat • iots be choſen,
Who ſhall have Power to puniſh in their time
T • e Crimes their Predeceſſors did commit
During their time of Rule.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: So ſhall the People
Not be to ſeek for Juſtice, but find eaſe
Unto their grievances, and the vile Minds
Of Avaritious and Ambitious Men
Be either puniſhed, or els Rebated.

sp.speaker: Icet.
sp.l: It cannot but content the People highly,
'Tis Coppied from ſo fair a Preſident.

sp.speaker: Hippa.
sp.l: And with you, and for you, and them, wee'l ſpend
Our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: We will do the like
With you, and for you, and thus link'd together,
We dare Contemn Cleander's Power.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: And blow
His Glorious hopes into the Air.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Be ſudden,
And we may take the Serpent in his Cell;
But our delaies may give the Monſter time
Of comming forth, and ſtrength to overcome us.

sp.speaker: Hippa.
sp.l: We will poſſeſs the People with the Glory
Of their long hidden liberties, with promiſe
Or Reſtauration, if it lies within
The power of friends, Money, or life to Compaſs.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: He that's beſotted to his fear, or Eaſe,
Will make his Patience prove his worſt diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: Return m • Obedience to the King Evander.
And this unto Miſſellus, tell him I
With all the force that Mona can afford me
Will wait upon his H • ghneſs and himſelf At Erix.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I ſhall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: How am I
Bound to the Gods for their ſuperlative goodneſs,
That here an offering of Mercy meets me
By their Dictation; I whoſe Treachery
Unto my King Merits ſevereſt Juſtice,
Am puniſhed with a Revengleſs Pardon,
Which is indeed my Torment, that I ſhould
Ever have bin ſo wicked 'gainſt a Prince
Deſerves ſo much good from me, but my Soul
Henceforth ſhall cleave faſt to this Principle,
"The longer growth Diſeaſes do indure,
"The more the Griefe, more famous is the Cure.

div.stage: Enter Hipparinus, Icetis, and the People caſting up their Caps, crying Liberty, Liberty.

div.head: ACT 5. SCE. 1.
div.stage: Enter Agathocles, Epecides, Hipparinus, Icetis, Antanter, and the People hawling Cleander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: TRaytors, hands off, 'tis Sacrilege to uſe
The Perſon of your King with ſuch Irreverence.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Our King—ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: People.
sp.l: Wee'l make you ſing another Song.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Have I deſerv'd ſo ill, that none wil give
A Death more honourable to me?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Thou haſt liv'd
Baſe, and muſt baſely die.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Forgive me Heaven,
And you bright Stars whoſe Luſtre I Ecclipſe
Here, to ſhine brighter there, Plead not againſt me,
But be as Mercifull as you are Innocent.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Wert thou the death of Archias and thy Daughter?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Ambition was, to which I gave conſent.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: And now you ſee the Pinacle from which
You muſt be tumbled down, away with him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yet hear me.

sp.speaker: People.
sp.l: Confeſſion's ti'd to Deſtiny, you ſhall with us.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: You ſee the deſperate effects that wait
On this thing called Monarchy, becauſe
It carries a continuance, and all
Men Naturally have an Ambition to
Make great their line, and families by ſucceſſion;
When ours doth blunt the Edge of ſuch Reſolves;
And no Man, were it not for th' Common good,
Would entertain the Office, being rather
A Place of care than Profit, in the which
Men muſt ſo ſquare their Actions, they may be
Able to ſtand the Peoples queſtioning,
When as their time of Government's expir'd.

sp.speaker: Epec.
sp.l: It is not ſo with Monarchy, Kings may
Commit what Outrages they pleaſe upon
The People, and none dare ſo much as think
They have done ill.

sp.speaker: Fell.
sp.l: If you pleaſe to walk that way
You may ſee Cleander ſwinging for his life.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.l: Oh by all meanes let's go.

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: It may be he may confeſs ſomething more.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: My Peoples troubles do afflict me more
Than all the wrongs and injuries they've done me:

sp.speaker: Miſſ.
sp.l: The Gods had loſt their Attribute of Juſt,
Had they not puniſh'd them with theſe Convulſions,
Whoſe fits direct their Senſe unto the ruine
They've brought upon themſelves now at their doors.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good Heaven divert it, I ſhall be more Chary
In ſpilling of their blood than of my own;
And I ſhall thinke it greater honour to me
(In purchaſing my own) to have my Temples
Surrounded with a peacefull Garland than
Obtain it by the Victory and Slaughter
Of my poor Subjects.

sp.speaker: Miſſell.
sp.l: 'Tis your mercy Sir,
sp.stage: Enter Planetius and Souldiers, Planetius kneels.
sp.l: With which you overflow—here is Planetius.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: I offer at your Highneſs feet a life
That has long ſince bin forfeited.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: The which
I give thee back; live to deſerve my favour.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: I would I could recover ſo much time,
As I have loſt, to ad unto the daies
I'm yet to ſpend, to ſerve you, this your Mercy
Does come ſo neer the temper of the Gods,
Fame cannot but record it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Has our Subjects
The knowledge that we live?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I did diſpierce it
Through all the parts of Mona:

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And how took they it?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Miraculouſly; but ſo, I might diſcover
Their Joy was unexpreſſible.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Wee'l have
Our Pardon (as we March) Proclam'd to all
Will come in to us; Clemency not force
Befits a King, Rigour makes People worſe.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs the King▪ March Gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter Antanter, and Souldiers paſs over the Stage, then, Enter Agathocles.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: 'Tis brave to be a King, his ſpirit's low
And baſe as Earth, that knows not how to uſe
The Power the Fates have put into his hands▪
And will accept of leſs; damn 'annuall Rule,
Shall I who dare do more than kill a thouſand,
Be Subject to the queſtioning of ten?
The People have put me in power, and I
Will make my beſt advantage on't; it is
But Juſtice to break faith with faithleſs Men.
Give me the Nod that ſtrikes a trembling in
The ſtiffe-neck'd People, and does make 'em keep
A diſtance and a duty; ther's no Glory
Like being Singular, hence idle honeſty
That ſleep'ſt thy time away, and art ador'd
By none but empty Sculls and tatter'd Jerkins;
There's no ſuch thing as vertue in thy Rags.
That, we prize to be vertuous and good
Merits its Eſtimation. Welcome Greatneſs,
Vertue reſides with thee. My hopes by this
Are by Antanter perfected, hee's here;
Now my beſt Genius tell me how much
I ſtand indebted to thee, is it done?

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: Done to a hair Sir, We ſurpriz'd 'm ſuddenly,
Truſs'd up the Magiſtrates to whom y'ad promiſ'd
Such glorious freedome, who did curſe and ſwear
At Death and Deſtiny. The Forts and Caſtles
Are all our own, and now we ſafely may,
Cry with one voice, long live Agathocles.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: How ſhall I make requitall for this Project
Which thou haſt more than form'd, perform'd ſo bravely?
I will Create thee Arch-Duke of Palermo,
And when I die, will leave the Kingdom to thee.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: But give me leave I pray Sir—
In whoſe Power
Lies it to make me Duke?

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: In mine, whoſe elſe?
Am I not thy King.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Pray who made you ſo?

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: The Gods.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Pray which of them? Have I bin Idle.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: No, Dear Antanter no; It was thy hand
Directed by the Gods that made me King.

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: Then 'twas my hand directed by the Gods
That made you King.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: Right, right Antanter.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: And now my hand directed by the Gods,
Will you un • King?—take him • nto your Charge.

sp.speaker: Agath.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Very right Sir, Charity begins
At home, and I'm not ſuch an Aſs to ſtand
To your reward, when I can pay my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: What doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To be what you would be,
That is, a King,

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: A King? of what?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Of better men than thou art—'tis a wrong
Unto our Honour to hold Parley with thee.
Off with his Head; It is a Death more Noble
Than you beſtow'd upon Cleander Sir,
Or Order'd for Icetis, or the Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: But do you hear Sir King.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Obey our Will—
And Sir, ſay y'are well dealt with▪

sp.speaker: Agat.
sp.l: Hell take you
And your dealing too; Heaven is thus juſt
With ſuch as fal from Vertue to their Luſt.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: So, he is gone, fallen in the Trap he laid
For th'Magiſtrates, whom I have but ſecur'd,
Till they allow my Power, or dye by it.
The Title King's indifferent to me,
Give me th' eſſentiall part, and let the ſhadow
Vaniſh, and be forgot. What had this Lord
More in him of a man, to draw Obedience
Than I, except his Title? and that had not
Vertue enough to ſave him from my wrath.
It is not birth, or blood, but thou dear Inſtrument,
That can defend, offend, raiſe or diſ-ſeate
High Potentates, and mak a Beggar great.
Be thou auſpicious Armed Mars to me,
And I'l adore no other Gods but thee.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: The Generall hearing of theſe diſtractions,
Has dr • wn his Army this way, and puts in
For title to the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Though he was
My Generall once, I'l ſcourge him into duty,
And make him know his diſtance, we will meet him.
Leave what force you can poſſibly allow
Here, to ſecure the People and the Garriſons
Now in our Cuſtody, leſt they Revolt,
Or become Mutineers, Hermocrates
Shall finde as tuffe a bus'neſs on't, as e'r
The Wars afforded him; Give double pay
To ſuch as will come in to us, and leave
His Party, ſince, that I am in, I'l through,
Though th' Kingdoms treaſury bleed for't, and lean famin
Feed on the People, 'till there ſcarce are left
The Image of a Man alive; 'twere baſe
Now to Retreat; fear gives a Coward place.

sp.speaker: Hermo.
sp.l: Is't poſſible Antanter dares do this.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Agathocles is beheaded, Hipparinus
With th'reſt of th' Magiſtrates of Palermo and
The Governour Icetis are ſecur'd.
The Forts and Caſtles all are in his Power,
And has ſurpriz'd the Treaſury.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: A brave fellow:
How long thinks he to keep this? I do wonder
Miſsellus or Planetius ſtir not 'bout it:
But they indeed are ſuch known enemies
To one another, neither of them dare
Peep forth, leſt tother be upon his back.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I know your Excellency will be the Man
Muſt make the Souldier flouriſh and be happy.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I and Atanter are the only Men
I ſee muſt go to Cudgels for't.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Alas,
Our force will ſcatter his, as Northerne winds
Diſperſe the leaves in Autumn.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: But he has
Th' advantage by the Treaſury, and Mony
Will purchaſe Men, and friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Victory
Will draw them all to us, I hope there is not
A Man amongſt us ſo in love with's life,
But he will ſacrifice it for your Excellence;
What ſay you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Our lives are his.

sp.speaker: Hermoc.
sp.l: I thank you fellow Souldiers;
Arm'd with you,
I dare Oppoſe the Deſtinies. He down,
The Guerdon of our Conqueſt is a Crown.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How poor and bare's this Province made? we ſcarce
Can get Proviſion for our Men and H • rſe.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: But we are neer the City of Monreall,
An that was wont t' abound with all Proviſion.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Have you inform'd th' Archbiſhop and the Magiſtrates
That we are drawing towards them,

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: We have
By by your Expreſs, and wonder that wee hear
No ſooner from them.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Diſobedient Guilt
Throwes me thus low for Mercy.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Here, riſe up

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Diſtracted ſhame ſo overcomes me Sir,
I cannot look your Highneſs in the face.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Return unto your Vertue, and we ſhall
Be happy in your friendſhip. Epecides
How doſt thou reliſh us?

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: As I would Sir,
The Author of my Being, Peace, and happineſs.
My Soul has wander'd all this while, and now,
With you, it is return'd to its firſt Station.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: But what has brought thee to Monreall? tell me.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: After Cleander's death, my friend Agathocles,
Whoſe breſt I thought had bin ſo Mann'd with Vertue
Ambition could not batter it, compli'd
With th' Souldiery, of which Antanter was
The Chiefe, to put the Magiſtrates to death.
No ſooner that Antanter had ſecur'd
The Forts and Caſtles, and made all his own,
But he begins to fall off from his Bargain
With the new King, and to himſelf does give
A Law to take his head off, and indeed
No Man could promiſe to himſelf a ſafety,
Unleſs he did ſubmit unto his Power,
To which I knew I could not bend my Heart,
And therefore for ſelf-Preſervation made
Bold with my Lord Archbiſhop.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: What is that
Antanter, whoſe Audaciouſneſs is ſo
Deſtructive to our Peace?

sp.speaker: Plane.
sp.l: He was an Officer
Under Hermocrates Mazares Generall.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: And now they both are tugging to undo
The Kingdom, and from eithers Ruine to
Raiſe to the Victor Glory.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Ah poor Cicily,
How haſt thou been beaten and banded to
Promote the ends of turbulent Spirited Men?
My Lords while they are ſtriving for the Maſtery,
What if we fell upon them?

sp.speaker: Miſſe.
sp.l: Very requiſite.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Let us bee private in't and do it ſuddenly,
But firſt wee'l have a Baiting at your houſe.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: You Highneſs will enrich me with the favour.

div.stage: Enter the Party of Hermocrates driving Antanters Party before them, then Antanter enters and reſcues his Party, beats the others off; Hermocrates enters with freſh ſupplies and beats them in: Then enter at one door Hermocrates, at the other Antanter.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Have I ſingl'd thee?

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: Sir know y'are Sawcy,
We uſe to keep at diſtance with ſuch fellowes.

sp.speaker: H • rmo.
sp.l: 'Tis likely; to come neer us may prove dangerous.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Fellow th'aſt greater honour done thee now
Than e' • the Wars beſtow'd on thee, thou grappl'ſt
With no leſs than a King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Of Kitchin-ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: I'l make thee do thy duty.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That's to beat you.
What will you take Sir for your Kingdom, now?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Your Head and Quarters Sir to fix on th' Gates.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: And this next touch to boot.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: 'sDeath, I think
've fool'd away my Courage;
How do you now Sir?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: As well as e'r I did Sir—have I reach'd you?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Your Arm's to ſhort, and your
Aim worſe;
By Heaven,
Had'ſt thou Indented with the Fates to live
But for a Minute longer, thus I'd cancel it

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And thus I meet thy Reſolution.

div.stage: Fall both on one another, being down they ſtrive with one another A great ſhout within.
Enter Evander, Miſſellus, Archbiſhop, Planetius, Epecides, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Give Order for the Magiſtrates
Enlargement.

sp.speaker: Hermo.
sp.l: Ah, how my Fate afflicts me with freſh Torments?
Evander living?

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: Whoſe Injuries lie heavy
Upon our Soules; moſt gracious Sir how e'r
Our lives have been diſturbance to your Kingdom,
In Death with you and it we ſue for Peace;
Forgiveneſs Royall Sir.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: We come not to
Poſſeſs our own with thoughts to bee Reveng'd▪
Or if we did, you have eſcap'd it, Heaven▪
Forgive you as we do.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: May never Forraign
Or home-bred Jars wither your Peacefull Lawrel.

sp.speaker: Anta.
sp.l: And thus our Enmity does end; thy hand.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Thy cheek—farewell.

sp.speaker: Antan.
sp.l: Plenty and Peace perpetually dwell among you—

sp.speaker: Planeti.
sp.l: Two as brave Spirits
As e'r Cicily bred.

sp.speaker: Epeci.
sp.l: The Magiſtrates are here Sir.

sp.speaker: Icet.
sp.l: Hipp. At your feet, Royall Sir we fall.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Riſe in our favour.

sp.speaker: Icet.
sp.l: Your Mercy has no Preſident.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Heaven make you ſtronger in your faith and duties.
Hereafter to us, what is paſt We Pardon.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.l: All th' lowring Aſpects of Malignant Stars,
That lately threatn'd ruin to this Kingdom,
Are at your Glorious Preſence ſunk beneath▪
Their primitive Conceptions.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Take up thoſe bodies.
My Lords, with your aſſiſtance we muſt do
A cure upon the Kingdom, in the ſeating
Its diſlocated joynts; we ſhall not take
Notice hereafter who amongſt you have
Had hands in her impairing, out receive you
With no leſs favour than the reſt, not doubting
But that the ſmart you have felt by theſe Changes,
Will draw you home to Conſtancy, and the Wooll
That has ſo violently been taken from
Your Sheep, for want of an Indulgent Shepherd,
Make you prize one the better.

sp.speaker: Arc. Epe. Hip. Icet.
sp.l: May Heaven transform our ſhapes when our hearts change

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Then are we ſtrong enough to Combate Fate,
And Cure the wounds thus made upon the State.
